results.title: Measure of care: Alligator Rivers region
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Alligator Rivers Region”.
Following an environmental impact study by Mr Justice Fox, the Australian Government set up the Office of the Supervising Scientist to carry out scientific research in the Alligator River region of Kakadu National Park to establish base-line figures which would enable scientists to monitor the mining activities. This documentary deals in some detail with this research, and discusses the problems associated with mining in such an unusual and beautiful part of Kakadu National Park. Narrated by Robyn Williams.

results.title: Impact of mining
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Alligator Rivers Region”.
The second film in a series looking at the work of the Supervising Scientist following the Fox Report on Uranium mining in the Kakadu National Park region of the Northern Territory. To monitor possible problems, scientific studies were carried out before work began. Shows some of the field work and by the use of interviews examines possible problems which could occur.

results.title: Alcheringa
results.brief_description: Bill Onus hosts this series of films on different aspects of the traditional lifestyle of Australian First Nations peoples.
results.description: Bill Onus hosts this series of films on different aspects of the traditional lifestyle of Australian First Nations peoples.
description_for_label: Bill Onus hosts this series of films on different aspects of the traditional lifestyle of Australian First Nations peoples.

results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Woman gathers food
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Alcheringa”.
To the women falls the task of collecting supplementary foods - such as witchetty grubs and yams. Use is made of a sharply pointed stick to dig under bark for grubs and to kill a lizard which wanders across their path; also to dig for yams. The daughter accompanies her mother on her daily walk and learns the art of food gathering.

results.title: Walkabout
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
An Aboriginal man and his wife undertake a pilgrimage to the sacred place of the Rainbow Serpent, the controller of rain, water and life on earth. They are shown walking to the coast through an uninhabited land, clambering down cliffs to the ocean. The man carries spears and always walks ahead. Their way of life in tribal times is clearly shown in this brief sequence, as the man carries two spears and walks ahead of his wife.

results.title: Turtle hunt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Alcheringa”
Shows how First Nations people use unique methods of locating and hunting turtles by wading into shallow pools and feeling for the hard shells with bare feet, grasping their necks by hand, and roasting in hot ashes.
results.description:

results.title: Trading
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Alcheringa”.
First Nations peoples from central and coastal districts trade their specialties among themselves, in particular weapons of the hunt and of war. Leaving his family at their inland mia-mia, a man travels through dense bush to barter with another, so that each may benefit from the other’s skills. They sit face to face and test each weapon for strength before returning with their new possessions. With Bill Onus.

results.title: Shellfish gathering
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Illustrates the seasonal migratory habits of inland First Nations people who travel to the coast to collect shellfish to augment their diet. The husband walks ahead and carries his fire sticks in his hair. His wife goes into the rock pools and quickly fills the string bag which hangs from her shoulder; cooks the fish in their shells in the hot ash; water is poured over the fire to cool the shellfish before they are removed and eaten.

results.title: Mutton birds
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Alcheringa”.
First Nations people gather eggs and hunt the mutton bird on small coastal islands. The birds are removed from their burrows, killed and plucked before being loaded onto bark floats to be carried through the surf back to the campfire.
